original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares close up on edge as trading hours extend
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stocks edged up on market close on Monday recording a turnover of 1.2 billion rupees as the market resumes to its old hours of trading, in the previous sessions the market generated revenue below a billion as banking sectors brought the index down, due to the long weekend and holidays, which dampened investor sentiment, an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index closed up 0.71 percent or 65.95 points to 9,322.85.

“The market still has thin share volumes because the long weekend and festive season is approaching, however the market was green today because the trading hours going back to its usual,” Ranjan Ranatunga of First Capital Holdings said.
Talawakelle Tea Estates had seen some notable interest over a 25% price gain and remarkable dividends being announced by the company, Ranatunga said.
Sri Lanka will not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and will engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary “optimization,” Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.
“The market is muted mainly due to the upcoming long weekend and fears of potential debt restructuring coming back,” Ranatunga said.
Some more domestic debt restructuring discussions have been scheduled for April 20, and investors are likely to wait for further clarity before investing.
The most liquid index, S&P SL20, closed up 1.74 percent or 80.30 points to 2,732.71.
Top gainers were Expolanka, Vallibel One and Ceylon Tobacco Company. Top contributor to revenue was the transport industry contributing 352 million rupees to turnover. (Colombo/Apr10/2023)
